 Here's how it is. There are two parts to our law, common law (established by published judicial opinions) and statutory law. Congress and the various legislatures pass statutory law (which is often a codification of common law), which is then interpreted by the judges. However, law is also created by the courts.
 
 One example of this is libel by the press. The first amendment guarantees a free press; but federal law punishes libel. The Supreme Court had to rectify these two conflicting issues, so they created a standard (actual malice), completely outside of the laws themselves. There are actually two standards: one for public individuals, recognizing the right of the press to criticize people in the public eye, and one for private individuals, recognizing the rights of a private individual to protect themselves against libel.
 
 Again, none of this is in any statute, but it's sound law.
